title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to qtkit development
text: goal guide help get contributing qtkit quickly possible. guide divided two main pieces: Filing bug report feature request issue. Suggesting change via pull request. Please note qtkit released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Contributing to qtkit development
text: filing issue, important thing include minimal reproducible example can quickly verify problem, figure fix . three things need include make example reproducible: required packages, data, code. Packages loaded top script, ’s easy see ones example needs. easiest way include data use dput() generate R code recreate . example, recreate mtcars dataset R, ’d perform following steps: Run dput(mtcars) R Copy output reproducible script, type mtcars <- paste. even better can create data.frame() just handful rows columns still illustrates problem. Spend little bit time ensuring code easy others read: make sure ’ve used spaces variable names concise, informative use comments indicate problem lies best remove everything related problem. shorter code , easier understand. can check actually made reproducible example starting fresh R session pasting script . (Unless ’ve specifically asked , please don’t include output sessionInfo().)

title: Contributing to qtkit development
text: contribute change qtkit, follow steps: Create branch git make changes. Push branch github issue pull request (PR). Discuss pull request. Iterate either accept PR decide ’s good fit qtkit. steps described detail . ’re familiar git github, please start reading: https://r-pkgs.org/software-development-practices.html Pull requests evaluated seven point checklist: Motivation. pull request clearly concisely motivate need change. Unfortunately neither Winston much time work qtkit days, need describe problem show pull request solves concisely possible. Also include motivation NEWS new release qtkit comes ’s easy users see ’s changed. Add item top file use markdown formatting. news item end (@yourGithubUsername, #the_issue_number). related changes. submit pull request, please check make sure haven’t accidentally included unrelated changes. make harder see exactly ’s changed, evaluate unexpected side effects. PR corresponds git branch, expect submit multiple changes make sure create multiple branches. multiple changes depend , start first one don’t submit others first one processed. Use tidyverse coding style. Please follow official tidyverse style. Maintaining consistent style across whole code base makes much easier jump code. ’re modifying existing qtkit code doesn’t follow style guide, separate pull request fix style greatly appreciated. ’re adding new parameters new function, ’ll also need document roxygen2. Make sure re-run devtools::document() code submitting. fixing bug adding new feature non-graphical function, please add testthat unit test. fixing bug visual output, please add visual test. (Instructions follow soon) ’re adding new graphical feature, please add short example appropriate function. seems like lot work don’t worry pull request isn’t perfect. ’s learning process members qtkit team hand help . pull request (“PR”) process, unless ’ve submitted past ’s unlikely pull request accepted . PRs require review approval least one member qtkit development team merge.

title: Documenting Datasets
text: Proper dataset documentation crucial reproducible research effective data sharing. {qtkit} package provides two main functions help standardize automate documentation process: create_data_origin(): Creates standardized metadata data(set) sources create_data_dictionary(): Generates scaffolding detailed variable-level documentation can use AI generate descriptions reviewed updated necessary

title: Documenting Datasets
text: Let’s start documenting built-mtcars dataset: template provides fields essential metadata. can either open CSV file spreadsheet editor fill programmatically, shown . ’s might fill mtcars:
code: # Create a temporary file for our documentation origin_file <- file_temp(ext = "csv")  # Create the origin documentation template origin_doc <- create_data_origin(   file_path = origin_file,   return = TRUE ) #> Data origin file created at `file_path`.  # View the template origin_doc |>   glimpse() #> Rows: 8 #> Columns: 2 #> $ attribute   <chr> "Resource name", "Data source", "Data sampling frame", "Da… #> $ description <chr> "The name of the resource.", "URL, DOI, etc.", "Language, … origin_doc |>   mutate(description = c(     "Motor Trend Car Road Tests",     "Henderson and Velleman (1981), Building multiple regression models interactively. Biometrics, 37, 391–411.",     "US automobile market, passenger vehicles",     "1973-74",     "Built-in R dataset (.rda)",     "Single data frame with 32 observations of 11 variables",     "Public Domain",     "Citation: Henderson and Velleman (1981)"   )) |>   write_csv(origin_file)

title: Documenting Datasets
text: can force overwrite existing documentation:
code: create_data_origin(   file_path = origin_file,   force = TRUE ) #> Data origin file created at `file_path`.

title: Documenting Datasets
text: Create basic data dictionary without AI assistance:
code: # Create a temporary file for our dictionary dict_file <- file_temp(ext = "csv")  # Generate dictionary for iris dataset iris_dict <- create_data_dictionary(   data = iris,   file_path = dict_file )  # View the results iris_dict |>   glimpse() #> Rows: 5 #> Columns: 4 #> $ variable    <chr> "Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width", "Petal.Length", "Petal.Widt… #> $ name        <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA #> $ type        <chr> "numeric", "numeric", "numeric", "numeric", "factor" #> $ description <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA

title: Documenting Datasets
text: OpenAI API key, can generate detailed descriptions: Example output might look like:
code: # Not run - requires API key Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-api-key")  iris_dict_ai <- create_data_dictionary(   data = iris,   file_path = dict_file,   model = "gpt-4",   sample_n = 5 ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   variable     name         type    description                        #>   <chr>        <chr>        <chr>   <chr>                              #> 1 Sepal.Length Sepal Length numeric Length of the sepal in centimeters #> 2 Sepal.Width  Sepal Width  numeric Width of the sepal in centimeters

title: Documenting Datasets
text: larger datasets, can use sampling grouping:
code: diamonds_dict <- diamonds |>   create_data_dictionary(     file_path = "diamonds_dict.csv",     model = "gpt-4",     sample_n = 3,     grouping = "cut" # Sample across different cut categories   )

title: Documenting Datasets
text: Create documentation first obtaining/creating dataset Adding new variables Modifying data structure Changing data sources Store documentation alongside data version control Include documentation paths project README

title: Documenting Datasets
text: {qtkit} package provides flexible tools standardizing dataset documentation. combining create_data_origin() create_data_dictionary(), can create comprehensive documentation enhances reproducibility data sharing.

title: Documenting Datasets
text: Package documentation: help(package = "qtkit") Related packages: {dataMaid}, {codebook} Project homepage

title: Publishing Analysis Artifacts
text: {qtkit} package provides several functions help publish analysis artifacts standardized way: write_kbl(): Save kable/kableExtra tables files write_gg(): Save ggplot2 plots files write_obj(): Save R objects files functions handle common tasks like: Automatic file naming based code chunk labels Directory creation Multiple output formats Consistent styling theming

title: Publishing Analysis Artifacts
text: Let’s create save simple table using write_kbl():
code: # Create a basic table mtcars_table <- mtcars[1:5, 1:4] |>   kable(format = "html") |>   kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped")  # Save to file write_kbl(   kbl_obj = mtcars_table,   file = "mtcars_table",   target_dir = "artifacts",   device = "png" ) #> file:////tmp/RtmpKuSrwI/mtcars_table6aef154d2e4f.html screenshot completed #> save_kable will have the best result with magick installed.

title: Publishing Analysis Artifacts
text: can customize output format styling:
code: mtcars_table <- mtcars[1:5, 1:4] |>   kable(format = "html") |>   kable_styling(     bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"),     full_width = FALSE   ) |>   row_spec(0, bold = TRUE)  write_kbl(   kbl_obj = mtcars_table,   file = "mtcars_styled",   target_dir = "artifacts",   device = "png",   bs_theme = "flatly" ) #> file:////tmp/RtmpKuSrwI/mtcars_styled6aef24e45a82.html screenshot completed #> save_kable will have the best result with magick installed.

title: Publishing Analysis Artifacts
text: Save ggplot2 plots write_gg():
code: # Create a basic plot p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) +   geom_point() +   theme_minimal()  # Save to file write_gg(   gg_obj = p,   file = "mtcars_plot",   target_dir = "artifacts",   device = "png" ) #> Saving 7.29 x 4.51 in image

title: Publishing Analysis Artifacts
text: Add custom themes formatting:
code: p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point(size = 3) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Car Weight vs Fuel Efficiency",     x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",     y = "Miles per Gallon",     color = "Cylinders"   )  write_gg(   gg_obj = p,   file = "mtcars_plot_styled",   target_dir = "artifacts",   device = "png",   width = 8,   height = 6,   dpi = 300 )

title: Publishing Analysis Artifacts
text: Use write_obj() save R objects later use:
code: # Create a filtered dataset mtcars_subset <- mtcars |>   filter(cyl == 4) |>   select(mpg, wt, hp)  # Save to file write_obj(   obj = mtcars_subset,   file = "mtcars_4cyl",   target_dir = "artifacts" )

title: Publishing Analysis Artifacts
text: objects saved artifacts directory, seen : Tables plots saved {qtkit} can easily restored. image formats, use knitr::include_graphics() function:  Objects can read back using dget(): [!TIP] Note tables plots need saved write_kbl() write_gg() functions restored. objects can saved restored using write_obj() dget() function well.
code: fs::dir_tree("artifacts") #> artifacts #> ├── mtcars_4cyl #> ├── mtcars_plot.png #> ├── mtcars_plot_styled.png #> ├── mtcars_styled.png #> └── mtcars_table.png # Display the saved plot knitr::include_graphics("artifacts/mtcars_plot.png") # Read the saved object restored_data <- dget("artifacts/mtcars_4cyl")  # Check the restored object glimpse(restored_data) #> Rows: 11 #> Columns: 3 #> $ mpg <dbl> 22.8, 24.4, 22.8, 32.4, 30.4, 33.9, 21.5, 27.3, 26.0, 30.4, 21.4 #> $ wt  <dbl> 2.320, 3.190, 3.150, 2.200, 1.615, 1.835, 2.465, 1.935, 2.140, 1.5… #> $ hp  <dbl> 93, 62, 95, 66, 52, 65, 97, 66, 91, 113, 109

title: Publishing Analysis Artifacts
text: Use consistent naming conventions Create organized directory structures Document output formats locations Include version control outputs appropriate Validate restored objects match originals

text: pkg_name Character string. name R package add BibTeX file. bib_file Character string. path name BibTeX file write . Default "packages.bib".

title: Add Package Citations to BibTeX File — add_pkg_to_bib
text: Invisible NULL. function called side effect writing BibTeX file.

title: Add Package Citations to BibTeX File — add_pkg_to_bib
text: function create BibTeX file exist, append . includes citations specified package currently loaded packages.

title: Add Package Citations to BibTeX File — add_pkg_to_bib
code: # Create a temporary BibTeX file my_bib_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".bib")  # Add citations for dplyr package add_pkg_to_bib("dplyr", my_bib_file)  # View the contents of the BibTeX file readLines(my_bib_file) |> cat(sep = "\n") #> @Manual{R-base, #>   title = {R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing}, #>   author = {{R Core Team}}, #>   organization = {R Foundation for Statistical Computing}, #>   address = {Vienna, Austria}, #>   year = {2024}, #>   url = {https://www.R-project.org/}, #> } #>  #> @Manual{R-dplyr, #>   title = {dplyr: A Grammar of Data Manipulation}, #>   author = {Hadley Wickham and Romain François and Lionel Henry and Kirill Müller and Davis Vaughan}, #>   year = {2023}, #>   note = {R package version 1.1.4}, #>   url = {https://dplyr.tidyverse.org}, #> } #>  #> @Manual{R-qtkit, #>   title = {qtkit: Quantitative Text Kit}, #>   author = {Jerid Francom}, #>   year = {2024}, #>   note = {R package version 1.1.0}, #>   url = {https://cran.r-project.org/package=qtkit}, #> } #>

what: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
title: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
text: function calculates various association metrics (PMI, Dice's Coefficient, G-score) bigrams given corpus.

title: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
code: calc_assoc_metrics(   data,   doc_index,   token_index,   type,   association = "all",   verbose = FALSE )

title: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
text: data data frame containing corpus. doc_index Column 'data' represents document index. token_index Column 'data' represents token index. type Column 'data' represents tokens terms. association character vector specifying metrics calculate. Can combination 'pmi', 'dice_coeff', 'g_score', ''. Default ''. verbose logical value indicating whether keep intermediate probability columns. Default FALSE.

title: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
text: data frame one row per bigram columns calculated metric.

title: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
code: data_path <- system.file("extdata", "bigrams_data.rds", package = "qtkit") data <- readRDS(data_path)  calc_assoc_metrics(data, doc_index, token_index, type) #>        y     x       pmi dice_coeff    g_score #> 1  word2 word1 1.8787708  0.7272727 -0.5191244 #> 2  word2 word2      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 3  word2 word3 0.7801586  0.4363636 -1.6177367 #> 4  word2 word4      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 5  word2 word5      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 6  word3 word1      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 7  word3 word2 1.4733057  0.8727273 -0.2314424 #> 8  word3 word3      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 9  word3 word4 0.3746934  0.3636364 -2.0232018 #> 10 word3 word5      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 11 word4 word1      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 12 word4 word2      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 13 word4 word3 1.0678406  0.7272727 -0.6369075 #> 14 word4 word4      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 15 word4 word5 0.7801586  0.4363636 -1.6177367 #> 16 word5 word1      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 17 word5 word2      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 18 word5 word3      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 19 word5 word4 1.4733057  0.8727273 -0.2314424 #> 20 word5 word5      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 21 word6 word1      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 22 word6 word2      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 23 word6 word3      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 24 word6 word4      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 25 word6 word5 1.8787708  0.7272727 -0.5191244

code: calc_df(tdm)

title: Calculate Document Frequency — calc_df
text: numeric vector document frequencies term

what: Calculate Gries' Deviation of Proportions — calc_dp
title: Calculate Gries' Deviation of Proportions — calc_dp
text: Computes Deviation Proportions (DP) measure developed Stefan Th. Gries. DP measures evenly distributed term across parts corpus. normalized version (DP_norm) returned, ranges 0 (evenly distributed) 1 (extremely clumped distribution).

title: Calculate Gries' Deviation of Proportions — calc_dp
code: calc_dp(tdm)

title: Calculate Gries' Deviation of Proportions — calc_dp
text: tdm term-document matrix

title: Calculate Gries' Deviation of Proportions — calc_dp
text: numeric vector normalized DP values term

title: Calculate Gries' Deviation of Proportions — calc_dp
text: Gries, S. T. (2008). Dispersions adjusted frequencies corpora. International Journal Corpus Linguistics, 13(4), 403-437.

title: Calculate Inverse Document Frequency — calc_idf
text: Computes inverse document frequency (IDF) term term-document matrix. IDF calculated log(N/df) N total number documents df document frequency term.

title: Calculate Inverse Document Frequency — calc_idf
code: calc_idf(tdm)

title: Calculate Inverse Document Frequency — calc_idf
text: tdm term-document matrix

title: Calculate Inverse Document Frequency — calc_idf
text: numeric vector inverse document frequencies term

what: Calculate Normalized Entropy for Categorical Variables — calc_normalized_entropy
title: Calculate Normalized Entropy for Categorical Variables — calc_normalized_entropy
text: Computes normalized entropy (uncertainty measure) categorical variables, providing standardized measure dispersion randomness data.

title: Calculate Normalized Entropy for Categorical Variables — calc_normalized_entropy
code: calc_normalized_entropy(x)

title: Calculate Normalized Entropy for Categorical Variables — calc_normalized_entropy
text: x character vector factor containing categorical data.

title: Calculate Normalized Entropy for Categorical Variables — calc_normalized_entropy
text: numeric value 0 1 representing normalized entropy: Values closer 0 indicate less diversity/uncertainty Values closer 1 indicate diversity/uncertainty

title: Calculate Normalized Entropy for Categorical Variables — calc_normalized_entropy
text: function: Handles character vectors factors input Treats NA values separate category Normalizes entropy range (0,1) : 0 indicates complete certainty (one category dominates) 1 indicates maximum uncertainty (equal distribution) calculation process: Computes category proportions Calculates raw entropy using Shannon's formula Normalizes dividing maximum possible entropy

title: Calculate Normalized Entropy for Categorical Variables — calc_normalized_entropy
code: # Calculate entropy for a simple categorical vector x <- c("A", "B", "B", "C", "C", "C", "D", "D", "D", "D") calc_normalized_entropy(x) #> [1] 0.9232197  # Handle missing values y <- c("A", "B", NA, "C", "C", NA, "D", "D") calc_normalized_entropy(y) #> [1] 0.9690223  # Works with factors too z <- factor(c("Low", "Med", "Med", "High", "High", "High")) calc_normalized_entropy(z) #> [1] 0.9206198

title: Calculate Observed Relative Frequency — calc_orf
text: Computes observed relative frequency (ORF) term term-document matrix. ORF relative frequency expressed percentage (RF * 100).

title: Calculate Observed Relative Frequency — calc_orf
code: calc_orf(tdm)

title: Calculate Observed Relative Frequency — calc_orf
text: tdm term-document matrix

title: Calculate Observed Relative Frequency — calc_orf
text: numeric vector observed relative frequencies (percentages) term

what: Internal Functions for Calculating Dispersion and Frequency Metrics — calc_rf
title: Internal Functions for Calculating Dispersion and Frequency Metrics — calc_rf
text: collection internal helper functions calculate various dispersion frequency metrics term-document matrices. functions support main calc_type_metrics function providing specialized calculations different statistical measures. Computes relative frequency (RF) term term-document matrix, representing often term occurs relative total corpus size.

title: Internal Functions for Calculating Dispersion and Frequency Metrics — calc_rf
code: calc_rf(tdm)

title: Internal Functions for Calculating Dispersion and Frequency Metrics — calc_rf
text: tdm sparse term-document matrix (Matrix package format)

title: Internal Functions for Calculating Dispersion and Frequency Metrics — calc_rf
text: numeric vector element represents term's relative frequency corpus (range: 0-1)

title: Internal Functions for Calculating Dispersion and Frequency Metrics — calc_rf
text: package implements metrics: Dispersion measures: Document Frequency (DF): Count documents containing term Inverse Document Frequency (IDF): Log-scaled inverse DF, emphasizing rare terms Deviation Proportions (DP): Gries' measure distributional evenness ranging 0 (perfectly even) 1 (completely clumped) Frequency measures: Relative Frequency (RF): Term frequency normalized total corpus size Observed Relative Frequency (ORF): RF expressed percentage (RF * 100) Implementation notes: functions expect sparse term-document matrix input Matrix operations optimized using Matrix package NA values handled appropriately metric Results returned numeric vectors calculation process: Sums occurrences term across documents Divides total corpus size (sum terms) Returns proportions 0 1

title: Internal Functions for Calculating Dispersion and Frequency Metrics — calc_rf
text: Gries, S. T. (2008). Dispersions adjusted frequencies corpora. International Journal Corpus Linguistics, 13(4), 403-437.

what: Calculate Frequency and Dispersion Metrics for Text Types — calc_type_metrics
title: Calculate Frequency and Dispersion Metrics for Text Types — calc_type_metrics
text: Calculates various frequency dispersion metrics types (terms/tokens) tokenized text data. Provides comprehensive analysis types distributed across documents corpus.

title: Calculate Frequency and Dispersion Metrics for Text Types — calc_type_metrics
code: calc_type_metrics(data, type, document, frequency = NULL, dispersion = NULL)

title: Calculate Frequency and Dispersion Metrics for Text Types — calc_type_metrics
text: data Data frame. Contains tokenized text data document IDs types/terms. type Symbol. Column data containing types analyze (e.g., terms, lemmas). document Symbol. Column data containing document identifiers. frequency Character vector. Frequency metrics calculate: - NULL (default): Returns type counts - '': available metrics - 'rf': Relative frequency - 'orf': Observed relative frequency (per 100) dispersion Character vector. Dispersion metrics calculate: - NULL (default): Returns type counts - '': available metrics - 'df': Document frequency - 'idf': Inverse document frequency - 'dp': Gries' deviation proportions

title: Calculate Frequency and Dispersion Metrics for Text Types — calc_type_metrics
text: Data frame containing requested metrics: type: Unique types input data n: Raw frequency count rf: Relative frequency (requested) orf: Observed relative frequency per 100 (requested) df: Document frequency (requested) idf: Inverse document frequency (requested) dp: Deviation proportions (requested)

title: Calculate Frequency and Dispersion Metrics for Text Types — calc_type_metrics
text: function creates term-document matrix internally calculates requested metrics. Frequency metrics show often types occur, dispersion metrics show evenly distributed across documents. 'dp' metric (Gries' Deviation Proportions) ranges 0 (perfectly even distribution) 1 (completely clumped distribution).

title: Calculate Frequency and Dispersion Metrics for Text Types — calc_type_metrics
text: Gries, Stefan Th. (2023). Statistical Methods Corpus Linguistics. Readings Corpus Linguistics: Teaching Research Guide Scholars Nigeria Beyond, pp. 78-114.

title: Calculate Frequency and Dispersion Metrics for Text Types — calc_type_metrics
code: data_path <- system.file("extdata", "types_data.rds", package = "qtkit") df <- readRDS(data_path) calc_type_metrics(   data = df,   type = letter,   document = doc_id,   frequency = c("rf", "orf"),   dispersion = "dp" ) #>   type  n  rf orf        dp #> A    A 20 0.2  20 0.1176471 #> B    B 20 0.2  20 0.1029412 #> C    C 20 0.2  20 0.1764706 #> D    D 20 0.2  20 0.1176471 #> E    E 20 0.2  20 0.1176471

title: Calculate Probabilities for Bigrams — calculate_bigram_probabilities
text: Helper function calculates joint marginal probabilities bigrams input data. processes data create bigrams computes probabilities along individual token probabilities.

title: Calculate Probabilities for Bigrams — calculate_bigram_probabilities
code: calculate_bigram_probabilities(data, doc_index, token_index, type)

title: Calculate Probabilities for Bigrams — calculate_bigram_probabilities
text: data data frame containing corpus doc_index Column name document index token_index Column name token position type Column name actual tokens/terms

title: Calculate Probabilities for Bigrams — calculate_bigram_probabilities
text: data frame containing: x: First token bigram y: Second token bigram p_xy: Joint probability bigram p_x: Marginal probability first token p_y: Marginal probability second token

title: Calculate Association Metrics — calculate_metrics
text: Helper function computes various association metrics bigrams based probability distributions. Supports PMI (Pointwise Mutual Information), Dice's Coefficient, G-score calculations.

title: Calculate Association Metrics — calculate_metrics
code: calculate_metrics(bigram_probs, association)

title: Calculate Association Metrics — calculate_metrics
text: bigram_probs data frame containing bigram probability data columns: p_xy Joint probability bigram p_x Marginal probability first token p_y Marginal probability second token association Character vector specifying metrics calculate

title: Calculate Association Metrics — calculate_metrics
text: data frame containing original probability columns plus requested association metrics: pmi: Pointwise Mutual Information dice_coeff: Dice's Coefficient g_score: G-score

title: Create Data Dictionary — create_data_dictionary
text: function takes data frame creates data dictionary. data dictionary includes variable name, human-readable name, variable type, description. model specified, function uses OpenAI's API generate information based characteristics data frame.

title: Create Data Dictionary — create_data_dictionary
code: create_data_dictionary(   data,   file_path,   model = NULL,   sample_n = 5,   grouping = NULL,   force = FALSE )

title: Create Data Dictionary — create_data_dictionary
text: data data frame create data dictionary . file_path file path save data dictionary . model ID OpenAI chat completion models use generating descriptions (see openai::list_models()). NULL (default), scaffolding data dictionary created. sample_n number rows sample data frame use input model. Default NULL. grouping character vector column names group sampling rows data frame model. Default NULL. force TRUE, overwrite file file_path already exists. Default FALSE.

title: Create Data Dictionary — create_data_dictionary
text: data frame containing variable name, human-readable name, variable type, description variable input data frame.

title: Create Data Origin Documentation — create_data_origin
text: Creates standardized data origin documentation file CSV format, containing essential metadata dataset's source, format, usage rights.

title: Create Data Origin Documentation — create_data_origin
code: create_data_origin(file_path, return = FALSE, force = FALSE)

title: Create Data Origin Documentation — create_data_origin
text: file_path Character string. Path CSV file saved. return Logical. TRUE, returns data frame addition saving. Default FALSE. force Logical. TRUE, overwrites existing file path. Default FALSE.

title: Create Data Origin Documentation — create_data_origin
text: return=TRUE, returns data frame containing data origin template. Otherwise returns invisible(NULL).

title: Create Data Origin Documentation — create_data_origin
text: Generates template following metadata fields: Resource name Data source (URL/DOI) Sampling frame (language, modality, genre) Collection dates Data format Schema description License information Attribution requirements

title: Create Data Origin Documentation — create_data_origin
code: tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") create_data_origin(tmp_file) #> Data origin file created at `file_path`. read.csv(tmp_file) #>                 attribute #> 1           Resource name #> 2             Data source #> 3     Data sampling frame #> 4 Data collection date(s) #> 5             Data format #> 6             Data schema #> 7                 License #> 8             Attribution #>                                                 description #> 1                                 The name of the resource. #> 2                                            URL, DOI, etc. #> 3         Language, language variety, modality, genre, etc. #> 4                         The dates the data was collected. #> 5                             .txt, .csv, .xml, .html, etc. #> 6 Relationships between data elements: files, folders, etc. #> 7                                     CC BY, CC BY-SA, etc. #> 8                                     Citation information.

title: Curate ENNTT Data — curate_enntt_data
text: function processes curates ENNTT (European Parliament) data specified directory. handles .dat files (containing XML metadata) .tok files '(containing text content).

title: Curate ENNTT Data — curate_enntt_data
code: curate_enntt_data(dir_path)

title: Curate ENNTT Data — curate_enntt_data
text: dir_path string. path directory containing ENNTT data files. Must existing directory.

title: Curate ENNTT Data — curate_enntt_data
text: tibble containing curated ENNTT data columns: session_id: Parliamentary session identifier speaker_id: Speaker's MEP ID state: Representative's state/country session_seq: Sequential position session text: Speech content type: Corpus type identifier

title: Curate ENNTT Data — curate_enntt_data
text: function expects directory containing paired .dat .tok files matching names, found raw ENNTT data 'https://github.com/senisioi/enntt-release. .dat files contain XML-formatted metadata attributes: session_id: Unique identifier parliamentary session mepid: Member European Parliament ID state: Country state representation seq_speaker_id: Sequential ID within session .tok files contain corresponding text content, one entry per line.

title: Curate ENNTT Data — curate_enntt_data
code: # Example using simulated data bundled with the package example_data <- system.file("extdata", "simul_enntt", package = "qtkit") curated_data <- curate_enntt_data(example_data)  str(curated_data) #> 'data.frame':	2 obs. of  6 variables: #>  $ session_id : chr  "EP-2020-001" "EP-2020-001" #>  $ speaker_id : chr  "MEP123" "MEP124" #>  $ state      : chr  "FR" "DE" #>  $ session_seq: chr  "1" "2" #>  $ text       : chr  "This is a sample speech from France." "This is another speech from Germany." #>  $ type       : chr  "test1" "test1"

what: Detect Statistical Outliers Using IQR Method — find_outliers
title: Detect Statistical Outliers Using IQR Method — find_outliers
text: Identifies statistical outliers numeric variable using Interquartile Range (IQR) method. Provides detailed diagnostics outlier detection process.

title: Detect Statistical Outliers Using IQR Method — find_outliers
code: find_outliers(data, variable_name, verbose = TRUE)

title: Detect Statistical Outliers Using IQR Method — find_outliers
text: data Data frame containing variable analyze. variable_name Unquoted name numeric variable check outliers. verbose Logical. TRUE, prints diagnostic information quartiles, fences, number outliers found. Default TRUE.

title: Detect Statistical Outliers Using IQR Method — find_outliers
text: outliers found: Data frame containing rows outlier values Prints diagnostic information quartiles fences outliers: Returns NULL Prints confirmation message

title: Detect Statistical Outliers Using IQR Method — find_outliers
text: function uses standard IQR method outlier detection: Calculates Q1 (25th percentile) Q3 (75th percentile) Computes IQR = Q3 - Q1 Defines outliers values outside (Q1 - 1.5IQR, Q3 + 1.5IQR)

title: Detect Statistical Outliers Using IQR Method — find_outliers
text: Variable name Q1 Q3 values IQR value Upper lower fence values Number outliers found

title: Detect Statistical Outliers Using IQR Method — find_outliers
code: data(mtcars) find_outliers(mtcars, mpg) #> Variable name: mpg #> Q1: 15.425 Q3: 22.8 IQR: 7.375 #> Upper fence: 33.8625 Lower fence: 4.3625 #> Number of outliers: 1 #>                 mpg cyl disp hp drat    wt qsec vs am gear carb #> Toyota Corolla 33.9   4 71.1 65 4.22 1.835 19.9  1  1    4    1 find_outliers(mtcars, wt, verbose = FALSE) #>                      mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb #> Cadillac Fleetwood  10.4   8  472 205 2.93 5.250 17.98  0  0    3    4 #> Lincoln Continental 10.4   8  460 215 3.00 5.424 17.82  0  0    3    4 #> Chrysler Imperial   14.7   8  440 230 3.23 5.345 17.42  0  0    3    4

what: Download and Extract Archive Files — get_archive_data
title: Download and Extract Archive Files — get_archive_data
text: Downloads compressed archive files URL extracts contents specified directory. Supports multiple archive formats handles permission confirmation.

title: Download and Extract Archive Files — get_archive_data
code: get_archive_data(url, target_dir, force = FALSE, confirmed = FALSE)

title: Download and Extract Archive Files — get_archive_data
text: url Character string. Full URL compressed archive file. target_dir Character string. Directory archive contents extracted. force Logical. TRUE, overwrites existing data target directory. Default FALSE. confirmed Logical. TRUE, skips permission confirmation prompt. Useful reproducible workflows. Default FALSE.

title: Download and Extract Archive Files — get_archive_data
text: Invisible NULL. Called side effects: Downloads archive file Creates target directory needed Extracts archive contents Cleans temporary files

title: Download and Extract Archive Files — get_archive_data
text: Supported archive formats: ZIP (.zip) Gzip (.gz) Tar (.tar) Compressed tar (.tgz) function includes safety features: Permission confirmation data usage Directory existence checks Archive format validation Automatic file cleanup

title: Download and Extract Archive Files — get_archive_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data_dir <- file.path(tempdir(), "data") url <-   "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/qtalr/qtkit/main/inst/extdata/test_data.zip" get_archive_data(   url = url,   target_dir = data_dir,   confirmed = TRUE ) } # }

what: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
text: Retrieves works Project Gutenberg based specified criteria saves data CSV file. function wrapper gutenbergr package.

title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
code: get_gutenberg_data(   target_dir,   lcc_subject,   birth_year = NULL,   death_year = NULL,   n_works = 100,   force = FALSE,   confirmed = FALSE )

title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
text: target_dir directory CSV file saved. lcc_subject character vector specifying Library Congress Classification (LCC) subjects filter works. birth_year optional integer specifying minimum birth year authors include. death_year optional integer specifying maximum death year authors include. n_works integer specifying number works retrieve. Default 100. force logical value indicating whether overwrite existing data already exists. confirmed TRUE, user confirmed permission use data. FALSE, function prompt user confirm permission. Setting TRUE useful reproducible workflows.

title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
text: message indicating whether data acquired already existed disk, writes data files disk specified target directory.

title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
text: function retrieves Gutenberg works based specified LCC subjects optional author birth death years. checks data already exists target directory provides option overwrite . function also creates target directory exist. number works greater 1000 'confirmed' parameter set TRUE, prompts user confirmation. retrieved works filtered based public domain rights USA availability text. resulting works downloaded saved CSV file target directory. information Library Congress Classification (LCC) subjects, refer https://www.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/lcco/ Library Congress Classification Guide.

title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data_dir <- file.path(tempdir(), "data")  get_gutenberg_data(   target_dir = data_dir,   lcc_subject = "JC",   n_works = 5,   confirmed = TRUE ) } # }

what: Save ggplot Objects to Files — write_gg
title: Save ggplot Objects to Files — write_gg
text: wrapper around ggsave facilitates saving ggplot objects within knitr documents. Automatically handles file naming directory creation, support multiple output formats.

title: Save ggplot Objects to Files — write_gg
code: write_gg(   gg_obj = NULL,   file = NULL,   target_dir = NULL,   device = "pdf",   theme = NULL,   ... )

title: Save ggplot Objects to Files — write_gg
text: gg_obj ggplot written. specified, last ggplot created written. file name file written. specified, label code block used. target_dir directory file written. specified, current working directory used. device device used saving ggplot. Options include "pdf" (default), "png", "jpeg", "tiff", "svg". theme ggplot2 theme applied ggplot. Default theme specified ggplot2 options. ... Additional arguments passed ggsave function ggplot2 package.

title: Save ggplot Objects to Files — write_gg
text: path written file.

title: Save ggplot Objects to Files — write_gg
text: function extends ggplot2::ggsave : Using knitr code block labels automatic file naming Creating target directories exist Supporting multiple output formats (PDF, PNG, JPEG, TIFF, SVG) Applying custom themes plots saving

title: Save ggplot Objects to Files — write_gg
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(ggplot2)  plot_dir <- file.path(tempdir(), "plot")  # Write a ggplot object as a PDF file p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +   geom_point()  write_gg(   gg_obj = p,   file = "plot_file",   target_dir = plot_dir,   device = "pdf" )  unlink(plot_dir) } # }

what: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
text: wrapper around kableExtra::save_kable facilitates saving kable objects within knitr documents. Automatically handles file naming, directory creation, supports multiple output formats Bootstrap theming options.

title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
code: write_kbl(   kbl_obj,   file = NULL,   target_dir = NULL,   device = "pdf",   bs_theme = "bootstrap",   ... )

title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
text: kbl_obj knitr_kable object written. file name file written. specified, name based current knitr code block label. target_dir directory file written. specified, current working directory used. device device used saving file. Options include "pdf" (default), "html", "latex", "png", "jpeg". Note Chromium-based browser (e.g., Google Chrome, Chromium, Microsoft Edge Brave) required system options except "latex'. suitable browser available, function stop return error message. bs_theme Bootstrap theme applied kable object (applicable HTML output). Default "bootstrap". ... Additional arguments passed save_kable function kableExtra package.

title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
text: path written file.

title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
text: function extends save_kable functionality : Using knitr code block labels automatic file naming Creating target directories exist Supporting multiple output formats (PDF, HTML, LaTeX, PNG, JPEG) Applying Bootstrap themes HTML output Preserving table styling formatting HTML output, function supports Bootstrap themes available kableExtra. default theme "bootstrap".

title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(knitr)  table_dir <- file.path(tempdir(), "table")  mtcars_kbl <- kable(   x = mtcars[1:5, ],   format = "html" )  # Write a kable object as a PDF file write_kbl(   kbl_obj = mtcars_kbl,   file = "kable_pdf",   target_dir = table_dir,   device = "pdf" )  # Write a kable as an HTML file with a custom Bootstrap theme write_kbl(   kbl_obj = mtcars_kbl,   file = "kable_html",   target_dir = table_dir,   device = "html",   bs_theme = "flatly" )  unlink(table_dir) } # }

what: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
text: wrapper around dput facilitates saving R objects within knitr documents. Automatically handles file naming directory creation, support preserving object structure attributes.

title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
code: write_obj(obj, file = NULL, target_dir = NULL, ...)

title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
text: obj R object written. file name file written. specified, label code block used. target_dir directory file written. specified, current working directory used. ... Additional arguments passed dput.

title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
text: path written file.

title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
text: function extends dput functionality : Using knitr code block labels automatic file naming Creating target directories exist Preserving complex object structures attributes Supporting R object types (vectors, lists, data frames, etc.) Objects saved function can read back using standard dget function.

title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ obj_dir <- file.path(tempdir(), "obj")  # Write a data frame as a file write_obj(   obj = mtcars,   file = "mtcars_data",   target_dir = obj_dir )  # Read the file back into an R session my_mtcars <- dget(file.path(obj_dir, "mtcars_data"))  unlink(obj_dir) } # }

title: qtkit 1.1.0
text: New features: Adds curate_enntt_data() curate ENNTT data downloaded GitHub . Adds curate_swda_data() curate SWDA data downloaded LDC . Bug fixes: Bug fix (#7): calc_type_metrics() now correctly allows type document arguments specified symbols can take values type document. Enhancements: Adds vignettes documenting data using publishing functions. Removes many external dependencies package.

title: qtkit 1.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-08-17 Adds calc_assoc_metrics() calculate association metrics two variables. Adds calc_type_metrics() calculate dispersion frequency metrics variable. Adds create_data_dictionary() create data dictionary dataset. Adds find_outliers() identify observations data frame outliers given variable. Adds get_gutenberg_data() download dataset Project Gutenberg. Adds add_pkg_to_bib() add package bibliography. write_gg() writes ggplot object file. write_kbl() writes knitr::kable object file. write_obj() writes R object file. Adds find_outliers() identify observations data frame outliers given variable. Notes: get_talkbank_data() postponed future release.

title: qtkit 0.10.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-06-24 Initial CRAN submission.
